markdown: Pascal Neis [announced](http://neis-one.org/2016/05/good-hashtags-in-osm/) in his blog that one can not only search changeset comments in the application [OSM Changesets](http://resultmaps.neis-one.org/osm-changesets#2/34.0/1.4). "You can now search for any term in any tag value of all OSM changesets," Pascal says.

You may have seen OSM diary entries by Mapbox's data team such as [this one](http://www.openstreetmap.org/user/nammala/diary/40127) showing potentially problematic changes to OSM.  Many of the issues listed in those were revealed by [OSMCha](http://osmcha.mapbox.com/), originally written by [Wille Marcel](https://github.com/willemarcel/osmcha).  In this [diary entry](http://www.openstreetmap.org/user/manoharuss/diary/40118) Manohar from Mapbox goes into more detail about OSMCha and what they have found from using it.

Pascal Neis [describes](http://neis-one.org/2017/01/reviewing-osm-contribution-1/) in a blog post his tools for QA in OSM
  [Latest OSM Changeset Discussions](http://resultmaps.neis-one.org/osm-discussions#2/36.0/-10.5) and
  [Find Suspicious OSM Changesets](http://resultmaps.neis-one.org/osm-suspicious#2/35.9/-10.4) 
(Please note there are many possibilities to filter and also there are relevant links that provide further information.)

Sajjad Anwar from Mapbox [writes](https://www.mapbox.com/blog/validating-osm/) about using [OSMcha](http://osmcha.mapbox.com/) and [OSM-compare](https://github.com/mapbox/osm-compare) to validate and analyse changes happening in OpenStreetMap. He urges the community to join the effort to keep OpenStreetMap the best map out there.

Wille Marcel [has restarted](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/wille/diary/40511) development on his [OSMCHA](http://osmcha.mapbox.com/) project. Its main objective is to help to detect potentially harmful OpenStreetMap edits. Wille asks for your feedback and suggestions for improvements.
[Who is commenting? An Overview about OSM Changeset Discussions](http://neis-one.org/2017/07/who-is-commenting-osm-discussions/), a new blog post by Pascal Neis.

Satoshi (user nyampire) [published](http://www.openstreetmap.org/user/nyampire/diary/42126) an idea for review workflow using OSMCha. He [asks](https://twitter.com/nyampire/status/900525653740535808) for feedback.  Note that current version of the iD editor does indeed support "review requested".
Wille Marcel, author of OSMCha, [suggests](https://github.com/openstreetmap/openstreetmap-website/issues/1618) on GitHub to add an API for user blocks to the OSM API.

Edoardo Neerhut [writes](http://blog.mapillary.com/update/2017/08/29/State-of-the-Map-2017-An-evolving-map-ecosystem.html) in the Mapillary Blog about the OSM ecosystem, [OSMCha](https://osmcha.mapbox.com/) from Mapbox and about the AI assisted road tracing of Facebook in Thailand.

Contributor nammala [posted](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/nammala/diary/42473) an OSM diary entry describing the latest updates to "[OSMCha](https://osmcha.mapbox.com/)".  OSMCha was originally [written](https://github.com/willemarcel/osmcha-django) by Wille Marcel; see [his diary](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/wille/diary/42478) for details of OSMCha's new API.

The contributor [ionr](http://www.openstreetmap.org/user/ionr) asks the German forum about [how to deal](https://forum.openstreetmap.org/viewtopic.php?id=60189) ![(de)](http://blog.openstreetmap.de/wp-uploads//2016/12/de.svg) with `review_requested=yes`. Besides the discussion, there are [tips](https://forum.openstreetmap.org/viewtopic.php?pid=669753#p669753) ![(de)](http://blog.openstreetmap.de/wp-uploads//2016/12/de.svg) on tools to find such tags: [Find Suspicious OpenStreetMap Changesets](https://resultmaps.neis-one.org/osm-suspicious?country=184&hours=24&mappingdays=-1&tsearch=review_requested%3Dyes&anyobj=t&comp=%3E&value=10&action=d&obj=w#6/51.337/10.800), [OSMCha](https://osmcha.mapbox.com/) and [osm-qa-feeds](https://tyrasd.github.io/osm-qa-feeds/).

Wille writes a [diary](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/wille/diary/42998) announcing a mailing list for [OSMCha](https://osmcha.mapbox.com/). This mailing list will be vital to ask general questions, make announcements regarding OSMCha, collaborate on plans and new features, and inform the group of changes.

On the talk mailing list, Michael Reichert [raises](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk/2018-January/080006.html) the question to what extent change record discussion comments can be created automatically. He also criticizes the new review feature of OSMCha.
Wille Marcel shares a [diary](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/wille/diary/43101) about the latest updates and enhancements to OSMCha.

Wille Marcel writes a diary highlighting the [new release of OSMCha](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/wille/diary/43287) - OpenStreetMap Changeset analyser which comes with many new features such as more flexibility in posting changeset comments and a new location filter.

Wille Marcel shared the recent and future improvements for [OSMCha](https://osmcha.mapbox.com/), a validation tool for OSM, in Milan at SotM 2018. The slides are available [here](http://wille.blog.br/improving-osmcha) and the video of the talk is on [YouTube](https://youtu.be/Cr9XTtwuvjg?t=24181).

A new version of OSMCha with the changes required by the GDPR will be released by the end of August. Read about what will change in  Wille's [diary post](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/wille/diary/44584).
manoharuss gives a [short introduction](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/manoharuss/diary/44899) in his user diary on how to use OSMCha to find suspicious edits in OSM.
... the OSM changeset analyser [OSMCha](https://osmcha.mapbox.com/)? It allows you to keep track of edits in changesets. Many different filters can be used when visualising changes in changesets.

OSMCha [received](https://osmcha.mapbox.com/) important updates. Now OSMCha is compliant with the GDPR legislation and it has a new way to receive flagged OSM features. Wille [published](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/wille/diary/45286) two [blog posts](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/wille/diary/46834) about this new release.

Wille Marcel, a GIS application developer from Brazil, [has been elected](https://openstreetmap.be/2018/12/29/en-motm-marcel-wille.html) as mapper of the month by OSM Belgium. He discovered OSM back in 2010 at an open source software conference and names the development of OSMCha as his biggest achievement.

Wille [published](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/wille/diary/47903)  a blog post that explains how to set up some tools to receive notifications from [OSMCha](https://osmcha.mapbox.com) via Telegram or e-mail. That way you will be notified whenever there are new changesets that match a filter you saved on OSMCha.
OSMCha now supports creating [groups of OSM mappers](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/wille/diary/368839), and either filtering or hiding changesets made by group members.

OSMCha is switching its domain to [https://osmcha.org](https://osmcha.org). Users will be redirected from the previous domain to the new one, but developers that use the API need to change their applications to avoid problems. See more on [https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/wille/diary/392289](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/wille/diary/392289).

Wille Marcel [outlined](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/wille/diary/395139) improvements recently made to [OSMCha](https://osmcha.org/). New features include filtering changesets based on metadata, visualisation of changesets with relations, and integration with the [MapRoulette micro-tasking service](https://blog.maproulette.org/2020/12/01/osmcha-%e2%9d%a4%ef%b8%8f-maproulette/).

![lead picture](https://weeklyosm.eu/wp-content/uploads/sites/4/2021/02/100000000.png =752x420)

OSM Changeset #100.000.000 by [Lamine Ndiaye](http://hdyc.neis-one.org/?Lamine%20Ndiaye) [[^1^](#wn553_24445)] | map data © OpenStreetMap contributors

The Swiss OSM Chapter, SwissOSM, launched the activity 'Project of the Month CH' inspired by the French Project-du-Mois and the German 'Focus of the Week'. The first Project of the Month (PotM) in June is about mapping schools. The trilingual website (DE, FR, EN) for PotM is still [under construction](https://potm.osm.ch/superset/dashboard/12/).

... [OSMCha](https://osmcha.org/) is a tool for checking OSM changesets for data quality? The tool was [developed](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/wille/diary/40511) by Wille Marcel in 2015, and Wille remains the maintainer.

Wille Marcel [announced](https://twitter.com/_wille/status/1452666614617448460) a new release of [OSMCha](https://osmcha.org/). This version provides a better user experience on smartphones and tablets.
User Bxl-forever [made](https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/115624709) the first changeset of 2022 (UTC) according to OSMCha.
... the new Twitter account [OSMChangesets](https://twitter.com/OSMChangesets)?

![lead picture](https://weeklyosm.eu/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/620_T_all.jpg =2000x739)

OSMCha with a new feature funded by Wikimedia Italy [[^1^](#wn620_26917)]  ©  OSMCha  | map data © [OpenStreetMap contributors](https://wiki.osmfoundation.org/wiki/Licence/Licence_and_Legal_FAQ)

[OSMCha](https://osmcha.org) now allows users to search changesets that affect a certain OSM tag. For example: you can find changesets that created, modified or deleted restaurants. For more details, see the Development Seed blog [post](https://developmentseed.org/blog/2022-05-31-more-powerful-osmcha).

... there are many ways to contribute regularly to OSM?

Desktop:
    [OSM Streak](http://streak.osmz.ru/)
    [MapRoulette](https://maproulette.org/)
    [Pic4Review](https://pic4review.pavie.info/#/)
    [Unmapped Places](https://resultmaps.neis-one.org/unmapped#5/47.100/9.800)
    [Find Suspicious OpenStreetMap Changesets](https://resultmaps.neis-one.org/osm-suspicious#2/10.1/14.4)
    [OSMCha](https://osmcha.org/)
    [NotesReview](https://ent8r.github.io/NotesReview/)
    [Many Tasking Managers](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tasking_Manager)

Smartphone:
    [StreetComplete](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/StreetComplete)
    [Every Door](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Every_Door)
    [Vespucci](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Vespucci)
    [OSMfocus Reborn](https://pfiers.net/projects/osmfocus-reborn/)
    [OSM Go!](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Osm_Go!)
    [Jungle Bus](https://junglebus.io/en/mobility-open-data-proudly-crafted-by-the-openstreetmap-community-2/)

We are sure we have forgotten some. Please write to us and let us know, we will add them next week.

... if you are using the Greasemonkey Addon for the Firefox browser, there's a powerful script that gives you multiple ease-of-use changes for openstreetmap.org? You will have direct access to Mapillary and KartaView links that point to the same map area and multiple tools from a sidebar such as OSMCha (for Changesets), OSM Deep History, and Nominatim (for other Objects), or a link to create an overpass history request when you’re looking at a note. Also, when you’re viewing your 'My Notes' page, you will have the option to filter only unresolved notes for a better overview. You can see the development process on [GitHub](https://github.com/OSM-de/osm-org-greasemonkey), or you can [install the script](https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/OSM-de/osm-org-greasemonkey@master/osm-org-greasemonkey.user.js) directly into Greasemonkey.
During the short outage of OSMCha martien-176 [noted](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/martien-176/diary/399998) some useful alternatives.

Włodzimierz Bartczak [reported](https://openstreetmap.org.pl/2022/osmp-w-chorwacji/) :PL-s: >>> [:EN-t:](https://openstreetmap-org-pl.translate.goog/2022/osmp-w-chorwacji/?_x_tr_sl=auto&_x_tr_tl=EN) that OpenStreetMap Poland and the Pedagogical University of Kraków are organising 'Peljesac Cartographic Training Ground', a week-long training camp for students under the guidance of experienced OSM editors. You can follow their activity by watching for the [#peljesac](http://resultmaps.neis-one.org/osm-changesets?comment=peljesac#10/42.9685/17.3735) hashtag in OSM changesets by using [osmcha](https://osmcha.org).

OSMCha has been [welcomed](https://www.openstreetmap.us/2023/02/osmcha_announcement) as an OSM US Charter Project. The Charter Project designation provides OSMCha with a sustainable home that allows the project to be governed by input and leadership from across the community, including corporate users and donors.

OSMCha is almost eight years old now. Running without consistent maintenance since June 2021, OpenStreetMap US has just [accepted](https://www.openstreetmap.us/2023/02/osmcha_announcement) it as a charter project along with [MapRoulette](https://www.openstreetmap.us/2023/03/maproulette_announcement). Wille Marcel [noted](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/wille/diary/401146) that this partnership will provide the structure to raise funds for development and hosting, and will also open the possibility for the entire OSM community to influence the future of OSMCha (Wille is the creator of OSMCha).

Wille Marcel, in a recent [presentation](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4xMzmjd9oyg) during the OpenStreetMap US Mappy Hour, showcased OSMCha, a powerful tool for OpenStreetMap data analysis and quality control. The tutorial dives into the various functionalities starting at the [5:14](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4xMzmjd9oyg&t=309s) mark, providing a valuable resource for OSM enthusiasts.
Citrula [wrote](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/citrula/diary/402383) about how to use OSMCha's RSS feed and filter features to review changesets for which a review has been requested.

The UN Maps Learning Hub has [launched](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:7153700858059272193) its OSM Advanced courses, starting with a course on validating data in OSM. It offers an initial guide to learning validation techniques and tools such as the OSM Tasking Manager validation steps, JOSM tools and plugins, Overpass, Osmose, Whodidit, OSMCha, then a guide to learning how to interact with OSM contributors, and finally a guide that proposes a specific validation workflow for different map features (places, land use, road network, hydrography, bridges, fords and culverts) with a long-term perspective. Feedback is welcome!

... that UN Mappers has [launched](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/un-mappers_validation-openstreetmap-unmaps-activity-7153700858059272193-wCr3) the '[OSM Advanced](https://mappers.un.org/learning/course/view.php?id=35)' course on the UN Maps Learning Hub under a CC-BY-SA licence? It now offers an initial guide to learning validation techniques and tools (such as OSM Task Manager validation steps, JOSM  tools and plug-ins, Overpass, Osmose, Whodidit, OSMCha), then a guide to learning how to interact with OSM contributors, and finally a guide that offers a specific validation workflow for different map objects with a long-term perspective. It is available in English, Spanish, French, Italian, Portuguese, and soon in Chinese. As this Learning Hub is based on Moodle, you will need to sign up to access it. If this is your very first connection, there is a privacy data statement to accept, then you can join the course. Any feedback is welcome!

Wille Marcel [explained](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/wille/diary/403465) the process of moving the OSMCha website from Mapbox's to OpenStreetMap US's infrastructure. The migration was completed on Tuesday 13 February.

Tobias Jordans [posted](https://en.osm.town/@tordans/112630052454798505) about his efforts to modernise the OSMCha tool by migrating the frontend to a new React-based framework, improving the UI/UX with Tailwind CSS, and tackling technical debt.

Development Seed celebrates a decade of OSMCha, [highlighting](https://developmentseed.org/blog/2024-06-04-osmcha/) its role in [ensuring](https://x.com/_wille/status/1798848659049918856) the quality of OpenStreetMap edits. The tool has evolved to integrate more tightly with mapping and validation processes, using AI/ML to improve detection of map vandalism and errors. Future plans include improving user interfaces, increasing community engagement, and expanding automated validation capabilities to maintain the high data standards of OpenStreetMap.

David Karlaš [updated](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/DavidKarlas/diary/402768#comment58795) his script that adds helpful buttons to the OpenStreetMap website. The updated script now includes direct links to OSMCha and the Level0 editor and works with the recently updated layout of the OpenStreetMap website.
